1, 2, 5, 17, and 245 are all solutions, from a quick search

7x−5∣3x2−2x−35  ⟹  7x−5∣(21x+1)(7x−5)−49(3x2−2x−35)=17107x-5\mid3x^2-2x-35\implies 7x-5\mid(21x+1)(7x-5)-49(3x^2-2x-35)=17107x−5∣3x2−2x−35⟹7x−5∣(21x+1)(7x−5)−49(3x2−2x−35)=1710 and now you just check all the divisors of 1710 and see which ones work.
checking the divisors is too tedious
doing a quick search doesn't tell you when to stop ;-)
(1710 is the resultant of 7x-5 and 3x^2-2x-35) (and indeed the solutions listed by Aaron are all of them, after a tedious search which took under a millisecond)

import Mathlib

example (x : ℤ) (h : 0 < x) : (3 * x ^ 2 - 2 * x - 35 ≡ 0 [ZMOD 7 * x - 5]) ↔ (x = 1 ∨ x = 2 ∨ x = 5 ∨ x = 17 ∨ x = 245) := by
  constructor
  · intro hdvd
    apply Int.modEq_zero_iff_dvd.mp at hdvd
    have h1710 : 7 * x - 5 ∣ 1710 := calc
      _ ∣ (21 * x + 1) * (7 * x - 5) - 49 * (3 * x ^ 2 - 2 * x - 35) := by
        apply dvd_sub
        · exact dvd_mul_left (7 * x - 5) (21 * x + 1)
        · apply dvd_mul_of_dvd_right
          exact hdvd
      _ = 1710 := by ring
    have hle : x ≤ 245 := by
      linarith [Int.le_of_dvd (by norm_num) h1710]
    lift x to ℕ using h.le
    norm_cast at hle ⊢
    -- max rec depth
    /-
    clear h170 h
    revert hdvd
    revert x
    decide
    -/
    interval_cases x <;> simp at hdvd h ⊢ -- there must be a better way
  · rintro (rfl | rfl | rfl | rfl | rfl) <;> decide

import Mathlib

example (x : ℤ) (h : 0 < x) : (3 * x ^ 2 - 2 * x - 35 ≡ 0 [ZMOD 7 * x - 5]) ↔ (x ∈ [1, 2, 5, 17, 245]) := by
  constructor
  · intro hdvd
    apply Int.modEq_zero_iff_dvd.mp at hdvd
    have h1710 : 7 * x - 5 ∣ 1710 := calc
      _ ∣ (21 * x + 1) * (7 * x - 5) - 49 * (3 * x ^ 2 - 2 * x - 35) := by
        apply dvd_sub
        · exact dvd_mul_left (7 * x - 5) (21 * x + 1)
        · apply dvd_mul_of_dvd_right
          exact hdvd
      _ = 1710 := by ring
    have hle : x ≤ 245 := by
      linarith [Int.le_of_dvd (by norm_num) h1710]
    interval_cases x <;> simp at *
  · simp; rintro (rfl | rfl | rfl | rfl | rfl) <;> decide
No idea if this is that better way, but these 245 simps didn't take much time.
What does that ⊢ do? (In Aaron Liu's proof)

Whilst it took my computer algebra package under a millisecond, it (rather annoyingly) takes Lean a lot longer :-( (at least it still actually terminates in a smallish amount of time). Mario has flagged this sort of thing (ITP users being now used to the fact that looping over 100 things takes a while) as being an idea which we really should be trying to move away from (i.e. by making it run more like a computer algebra package)
norm_cast at hle ⊢ means "run norm_cast on both hle and the goal"

I was trying to extract a part of a bigger question, in which both x and y = (3x^2-2x-35)/(7x-5) have to be positive integers.
The answer to THAT is supposed to be: only x=1,2.
Obviously ZMOD does not capture that exactly.
spamegg has marked this topic as unresolved.
I think ZMOD does a good job of that but you could also use dvd
spamegg has marked this topic as resolved.

here's a quick and dirty proof which works faster:

set_option maxRecDepth 1710 in
lemma aux : Nat.divisors 1710 = {1, 2, 3, 5, 6, 9, 10, 15, 18, 19, 30, 38, 45, 57, 90, 95,
  114, 171, 190, 285, 342, 570, 855, 1710} := by decide

example (x : ℤ) (h : 0 < x) : (3 * x ^ 2 - 2 * x - 35 ≡ 0 [ZMOD 7 * x - 5]) ↔ (x = 1 ∨ x = 2 ∨ x = 5 ∨ x = 17 ∨ x = 245) := by
  constructor
  · intro hdvd
    apply Int.modEq_zero_iff_dvd.mp at hdvd
    have h1710 : 7 * x - 5 ∣ 1710 := calc
      _ ∣ (21 * x + 1) * (7 * x - 5) - 49 * (3 * x ^ 2 - 2 * x - 35) :=
        dvd_sub (dvd_mul_left (7 * x - 5) (21 * x + 1)) (dvd_mul_of_dvd_right hdvd _)
      _ = 1710 := by ring
    lift x to ℕ using h.le
    generalize hy : 7 * x - 5 = y
    have hx : 5 ≤ 7 * x := by linarith
    have : y ∣ 1710 := by
      rw [← hy, ← Int.ofNat_dvd, Nat.cast_sub hx]
      exact mod_cast h1710
    have hy' : y ∈ Nat.divisors 1710 := by simpa
    rw [aux] at hy'
    have hy'' : 7 ∣ y + 5 := by omega
    obtain rfl : x = (y + 5) / 7 := by omega
    clear h1710 hy h hx this
    revert y
    decide
  · rintro (rfl | rfl | rfl | rfl | rfl) <;> decide

And here is an even quicker and even dirtier tactic which will evaluate Nat.divisors n for explicit numerals n: 

import Mathlib

section

open Lean Elab Meta Tactic

simproc Nat.divisorsEq (Nat.divisors _) := fun e => do
  unless e.isAppOfArity `Nat.divisors 1 do return .continue
  let some n ← fromExpr? e.appArg! | return .continue
  let rhs ← mkAppM `List.toFinset #[toExpr (n.divisors.sort (· ≤ ·))]
  let pf ← Meta.mkDecideProof (← mkEq e rhs)
  return .done {expr := rhs, proof? := pf}

macro "computeDivisors" : tactic =>
  `(tactic| simp only [Nat.divisorsEq, List.toFinset_cons, List.toFinset_nil, insert_emptyc_eq])

end

example :
    Nat.divisors 1710 = {1, 2, 3, 5, 6, 9, 10, 15, 18, 19, 30, 38, 45, 57, 90, 95, 114, 171, 190, 285, 342, 570, 855, 1710} := by
  computeDivisors

example : Nat.divisors 57 = {1, 3, 19, 57} := by
  computeDivisors

example : 2 ≤ Finset.card (Nat.divisors 3) := by
  computeDivisors
  decide
